<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 193, 366, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 170, 905, 187]]<|/det|>
0625/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 194, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
February/March 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 216, 905, 231]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 246, 505, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 285]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 286, 539, 317]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 336, 228, 351]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 352, 115, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 352, 599, 368]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 368, 907, 399]]<|/det|>
For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 399, 578, 414]]<|/det|>
Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 415, 277, 429]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 430, 868, 460]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 460, 327, 475]]<|/det|>
Do not use correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 476, 364, 491]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 492, 329, 507]]<|/det|>
You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 507, 680, 523]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(9.8\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 565, 570, 615]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 40. Each correct answer will score one mark. Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 751, 89]]<|/det|> A student has a measuring cylinder containing water and also has a balance. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 720, 120]]<|/det|> Which of these could she use to find the volume of a small metal sphere? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 133, 353, 150]]<|/det|> She has no other apparatus. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 160, 134, 178]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 160, 656, 178]]<|/det|> either the measuring cylinder containing water or the balance <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 188, 131, 205]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 188, 520, 205]]<|/det|> the measuring cylinder containing water only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 214, 133, 231]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 214, 291, 231]]<|/det|> the balance only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 240, 133, 257]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 240, 537, 257]]<|/det|> neither the measuring cylinder nor the balance <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 284, 96, 301]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 282, 836, 301]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a solid object on a flat surface, with two forces acting on the object. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 310, 645, 415]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 428, 457, 446]]<|/det|> What is the resultant force on the object? Forces P, Q and R act on the beam. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 480, 829, 616]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 629, 339, 647]]<|/det|> Which equation is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 658, 134, 676]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 658, 368, 676]]<|/det|> \((\mathsf{P}\times \mathsf{c}) + (\mathsf{Q}\times \mathsf{b}) = (\mathsf{R}\times \mathsf{a})\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 686, 131, 704]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 686, 368, 704]]<|/det|> \((\mathsf{P}\times \mathsf{c}) - (\mathsf{Q}\times \mathsf{b}) = (\mathsf{R}\times \mathsf{a})\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 713, 133, 731]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 713, 368, 731]]<|/det|> \((\mathsf{P}\times \mathsf{d}) + (\mathsf{Q}\times \mathsf{b}) = (\mathsf{R}\times \mathsf{a})\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 740, 133, 758]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 740, 368, 758]]<|/det|> \((\mathsf{P}\times \mathsf{d}) - (\mathsf{Q}\times \mathsf{b}) = (\mathsf{R}\times \mathsf{a})\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 109, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 72, 520, 89]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a pan used for cooking food. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 97, 680, 250]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 262, 920, 297]]<|/det|> Which row is correct for the materials used to make the base of the pan and the handle of the pan? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 306, 670, 435]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 462, 107, 479]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 462, 833, 479]]<|/det|> Solar heating panels consist of pipes carrying water that absorb radiation from the Sun. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 492, 922, 526]]<|/det|> Which texture and colour is the surface of the pipes so that the temperature of the water rises at the quickest rate? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 536, 133, 554]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 536, 233, 553]]<|/det|> dull black <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 562, 133, 580]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 562, 233, 580]]<|/det|> dull white <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 588, 133, 606]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 588, 248, 606]]<|/det|> shiny black <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 615, 133, 632]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 615, 248, 632]]<|/det|> shiny white <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 658, 106, 676]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 658, 920, 691]]<|/det|> When pollen grains in water are viewed through a microscope, they are seen to be in continuous, rapid, random motion. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 702, 517, 720]]<|/det|> What causes a pollen grain to move in this way? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 731, 133, 749]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 731, 418, 749]]<|/det|> convection currents in the water <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 758, 133, 776]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 758, 514, 776]]<|/det|> bombardment by a single molecule of water <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 785, 133, 803]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 785, 645, 802]]<|/det|> uneven bombardment on different sides by water molecules <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 810, 133, 828]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 810, 428, 828]]<|/det|> collision with another pollen grain

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 574, 89]]<|/det|> A circular, flat-bottomed dish contains \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 739, 119]]<|/det|> Students are asked how to increase the rate at which the water evaporates. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 351, 149]]<|/det|> Their suggestions are listed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 161, 774, 180]]<|/det|> student 1 Pour the water into a flat-bottomed dish of larger diameter. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 188, 494, 206]]<|/det|> student 2 Cool the dish and water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 214, 675, 232]]<|/det|> student 3 Create a current of air over the dish with a fan. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 243, 584, 261]]<|/det|> Which suggestions will increase the rate of evaporation? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 272, 138, 289]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 272, 240, 289]]<|/det|> 1, 2 and 3 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 272, 306, 289]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 272, 425, 289]]<|/det|> 1 and 2 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 272, 475, 289]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 272, 593, 289]]<|/det|> 1 and 3 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 272, 636, 289]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 272, 759, 289]]<|/det|> 2 and 3 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 317, 107, 335]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 317, 673, 335]]<|/det|> Matter consists of very small particles in a continual state of motion. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 348, 598, 365]]<|/det|> Which row describes the behaviour of particles in a liquid? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 375, 636, 524]]<|/det|>
force between particlesmotion of particles
Astrongmove randomly at high speed
Bstrongvibrate, but change positions
Cweakvibrate in fixed positions
Dweakmove randomly at high speed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 488, 581, 507]]<|/det|> The specific heat capacity of aluminium is \(900 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \circ \text{C})\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 518, 621, 537]]<|/det|> What is the maximum possible temperature rise in the block? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 547, 138, 565]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 548, 191, 565]]<|/det|> 9℃ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[281, 548, 311, 565]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[320, 548, 368, 565]]<|/det|> 20℃ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 548, 476, 565]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 548, 534, 565]]<|/det|> 25℃ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 548, 635, 565]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 548, 710, 565]]<|/det|> 225℃ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 593, 106, 611]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 593, 349, 611]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a wave. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 618, 880, 780]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 795, 574, 814]]<|/det|> Which dimensions describe the properties of the wave? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 824, 134, 842]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 824, 364, 842]]<|/det|> P = amplitude, S = speed <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 851, 134, 868]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 851, 379, 868]]<|/det|> P = speed, Q = wavelength <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 877, 134, 895]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 877, 410, 895]]<|/det|> R = amplitude, Q = wavelength <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 903, 133, 921]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 903, 408, 921]]<|/det|> R = amplitude, S = wavelength

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 257, 106, 275]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 256, 920, 291]]<|/det|> The range of audible frequencies for elephants is \(10\mathrm{Hz}\) to \(12 000\mathrm{Hz}\), and for horses is \(55\mathrm{Hz}\) to \(33 000\mathrm{Hz}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 301, 871, 320]]<|/det|> Which statement about the range of audible frequencies for a healthy human ear is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 330, 134, 348]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 330, 752, 348]]<|/det|> The human ear can hear all sounds heard by both elephants and horses. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 357, 134, 375]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 356, 890, 375]]<|/det|> The human ear can hear all sounds heard by elephants but not all those heard by horses. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 383, 134, 401]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 383, 890, 400]]<|/det|> The human ear can hear all sounds heard by horses but not all those heard by elephants. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 409, 134, 427]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 409, 861, 427]]<|/det|> The human ear cannot hear all sounds heard by elephants nor those heard by horses.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 484, 89]]<|/det|>
An object is placed in front of a plane mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 813, 120]]<|/det|>
The ray diagram shows the reflection of one ray of light from the object by the mirror.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 128, 707, 230]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 243, 544, 262]]<|/det|>
Where does the mirror form an image of the object?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[297, 273, 318, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 657, 532, 675]]<|/det|>
Light refracts as it enters glass from air, as shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[369, 688, 630, 841]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 853, 598, 872]]<|/det|>
Which expression is equal to the refractive index of glass?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 884, 134, 903]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 880, 203, 920]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{\sin\theta_{1}}{\sin\theta_{2}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[278, 880, 298, 900]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[303, 878, 430, 920]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{\sin\theta_{1}}{\sin(90^{\circ} - \theta_{2})}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 880, 470, 900]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 878, 598, 920]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{\sin(90^{\circ} - \theta_{1})}{\sin\theta_{2}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[618, 880, 636, 900]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[653, 880, 764, 920]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{\sin(90^{\circ} - \theta_{1})}{\sin(90^{\circ} - \theta_{2})}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> Light travelling at a speed of \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\) strikes the surface of a glass block and undergoes refraction as it enters the block. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 117, 712, 136]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a ray of this light before and after it enters the block. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[307, 144, 685, 311]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 324, 437, 343]]<|/det|> What is the speed of light in the glass? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 354, 128, 371]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 354, 267, 371]]<|/det|> \(1.8 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 381, 128, 400]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 381, 267, 400]]<|/det|> \(2.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 409, 128, 428]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 409, 267, 427]]<|/det|> \(4.5 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 437, 128, 456]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 437, 267, 454]]<|/det|> \(5.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 479, 106, 497]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 479, 680, 497]]<|/det|> Which row about converging lenses and diverging lenses is correct? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 508, 922, 638]]<|/det|>
converging lensesdiverging lenses
Aalways produce inverted imagescan focus a parallel beam of light
Bcan be used as magnifying glassesdo not have a principal focus
Ccan be used to correct short-sightednessare usually thinner than converging lenses
Dcan produce real and virtual imagescan be used to correct short-sightedness

weakest magnetic fieldstrongest magnetic field
APQ
BPR

DQR
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 479, 104, 497]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 479, 675, 497]]<|/det|> A nichrome wire, P, has a length of \(1.0 \text{m}\) and a diameter of \(1.0 \text{mm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 510, 742, 528]]<|/det|> A second nichrome wire, Q, has a length of \(2.0 \text{m}\) and a diameter of \(2.0 \text{mm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 540, 703, 559]]<|/det|> Which statement correctly compares the resistance of Q with that of P? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 570, 133, 588]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 570, 599, 588]]<|/det|> The resistance of Q is one-quarter the resistance of P. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 596, 133, 615]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 596, 571, 615]]<|/det|> The resistance of Q is one-half the resistance of P. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 623, 133, 641]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 623, 604, 641]]<|/det|> The resistance of Q is the same as the resistance of P. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 650, 133, 667]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 650, 584, 667]]<|/det|> The resistance of Q is four times the resistance of P. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 692, 106, 710]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 692, 346, 710]]<|/det|> A student has two resistors. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 723, 761, 741]]<|/det|> One resistor has a resistance of \(2.0 \Omega\) and the other has a resistance of \(40 \text{k} \Omega\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 753, 348, 771]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 783, 133, 801]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 783, 662, 801]]<|/det|> When connected in parallel, the combined resistance is \(1.9 \Omega\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 810, 133, 828]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 810, 662, 828]]<|/det|> When connected in parallel, the combined resistance is \(2.0 \Omega\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 838, 133, 856]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 838, 648, 856]]<|/det|> When connected in series, the combined resistance is \(1.9 \Omega\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 866, 133, 883]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 866, 648, 883]]<|/det|> When connected in series, the combined resistance is \(42 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 526, 104, 545]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 526, 668, 545]]<|/det|> A student is investigating the count rate of a radioactive substance. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 556, 598, 575]]<|/det|> How must he adjust his reading for the background count? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 585, 134, 603]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 585, 490, 603]]<|/det|> Add the background count to his reading. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 612, 134, 630]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 612, 643, 630]]<|/det|> Ignore the background count as it will not affect his reading. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 638, 134, 657]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 638, 551, 657]]<|/det|> Subtract the background count from his reading. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 664, 134, 682]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 664, 618, 682]]<|/det|> Take repeat readings to eliminate the background count. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 708, 107, 726]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 708, 411, 726]]<|/det|> What occurs during nuclear fusion? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 736, 134, 754]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 736, 591, 754]]<|/det|> Two light atomic nuclei join together and emit energy. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 763, 134, 781]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 763, 613, 781]]<|/det|> Two light atomic nuclei join together and absorb energy. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 789, 134, 808]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 789, 551, 808]]<|/det|> A heavy atomic nucleus splits and emits energy. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 816, 134, 834]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 816, 574, 834]]<|/det|> A heavy atomic nucleus splits and absorbs energy.
